publicwhip.spmotion: *S2M-5637♦ Jackie Baillie: Changing Places—That the Parliament recognises that around 3,500 people in Scotland with profound and multiple learning disabilities, as well as many thousands of other disabled people, cannot use standard accessible toilets and require public toilets with enough space for disabled people and their carers along with the right equipment, including a height adjustable changing bench and a hoist; notes the positive examples of facilities in the Meadow Centre in Dumbarton and in the Vale of Leven leisure centre; supports the Changing Places Campaign, launched by the Changing Places Consortium of MENCAP, PAMIS (Promoting a More Inclusive Society), Dumfries and Galloway Council, Nottingham City Council, the Valuing People Support Team and the Scottish Executive’s "Same As You" team, which is calling for more of these toilets to be installed in public places to enable disabled people and their carers to be active citizens, and notes that the Cross Party Group on Learning Disability welcomes all efforts, including those of the Parliament, to ensure that provision is made for people with profound and multiple learning disabilities.

S2M-5637♦ Jackie Baillie: Changing Places—That the Parliament recognises that around 3,500 people in Scotland with profound and multiple learning disabilities, as well as many thousands of other disabled people, cannot use standard accessible toilets and require public toilets with enough space for disabled people and their carers along with the right equipment, including a height adjustable changing bench and a hoist; notes the positive examples of facilities in the Meadow Centre in Dumbarton and in the Vale of Leven leisure centre; supports the Changing Places Campaign, launched by the Changing Places Consortium of MENCAP, PAMIS (Promoting a More Inclusive Society), Dumfries and Galloway Council, Nottingham City Council, the Valuing People Support Team and the Scottish Executive’s "Same As You" team, which is calling for more of these toilets to be installed in public places to enable disabled people and their carers to be active citizens, and notes that the Cross Party Group on Learning Disability welcomes all efforts, including those of the Parliament, to ensure that provision is made for people with profound and multiple learning disabilities.
S2M-5637♦ Changing Places (lodged on 22 February 2007) Michael McMahon*

S2M-5637*#* Jackie Baillie: Changing Places—That the Parliament recognises that around 3,500 people in Scotland with profound and multiple learning disabilities, as well as many thousands of other disabled people, cannot use standard accessible toilets and require public toilets with enough space for disabled people and their carers along with the right equipment, including a height adjustable changing bench and a hoist; notes the positive examples of facilities in the Meadow Centre in Dumbarton and in the Vale of Leven leisure centre; supports the Changing Places Campaign, launched by the Changing Places Consortium of MENCAP, PAMIS (Promoting a More Inclusive Society), Dumfries and Galloway Council, Nottingham City Council, the Valuing People Support Team and the Scottish Executive’s "Same As You" team, which is calling for more of these toilets to be installed in public places to enable disabled people and their carers to be active citizens, and notes that the Cross Party Group on Learning Disability welcomes all efforts, including those of the Parliament, to ensure that provision is made for people with profound and multiple learning disabilities. Supported by: Patrick Harvie*, Bill Butler*, Margaret Jamieson*, Rosie Kane*, Robin Harper*, Alex Neil*, Trish Godman*, Eleanor Scott*, Mrs Mary Mulligan*, Murray Tosh*, Frances Curran* Motions and amendments which have attracted additional support

S2M-5637# Jackie Baillie: Changing Places—That the Parliament recognises that around 3,500 people in Scotland with profound and multiple learning disabilities, as well as many thousands of other disabled people, cannot use standard accessible toilets and require public toilets with enough space for disabled people and their carers along with the right equipment, including a height adjustable changing bench and a hoist; notes the positive examples of facilities in the Meadow Centre in Dumbarton and in the Vale of Leven leisure centre; supports the Changing Places Campaign, launched by the Changing Places Consortium of MENCAP, PAMIS (Promoting a More Inclusive Society), Dumfries and Galloway Council, Nottingham City Council, the Valuing People Support Team and the Scottish Executive’s "Same As You" team, which is calling for more of these toilets to be installed in public places to enable disabled people and their carers to be active citizens, and notes that the Cross Party Group on Learning Disability welcomes all efforts, including those of the Parliament, to ensure that provision is made for people with profound and multiple learning disabilities. Supported by: Michael McMahon, Patrick Harvie, Bill Butler, Margaret Jamieson, Rosie Kane, Robin Harper, Alex Neil, Trish Godman, Eleanor Scott, Mrs Mary Mulligan, Murray Tosh, Frances Curran, Helen Eadie, Mr Kenneth Macintosh, Nora Radcliffe, Chris Ballance, Mike Pringle, Ms Rosemary Byrne, Linda Fabiani, Donald Gorrie, Karen Gillon, Carolyn Leckie, Mr Frank McAveety, Ms Wendy Alexander, Marilyn Livingstone, Dr Sylvia Jackson, Bruce Crawford, Tricia Marwick, Shiona Baird, Susan Deacon, Mr Jamie Stone, Murdo Fraser, Mrs Nanette Milne, Ms Maureen Watt, Marlyn Glen, Kate Maclean, Mr Ted Brocklebank, Mr John Swinney, Elaine Smith, Mr Andrew Arbuckle, Dennis Canavan, Mr David Davidson, Mr Andrew Welsh, Michael Matheson, Alasdair Morgan, Dave Petrie, Karen Whitefield, Lord James Douglas-Hamilton, Maureen Macmillan, Cathy Peattie, Phil Gallie, Margaret Mitchell, Peter Peacock, Ms Sandra White, Jim Mather, John Farquhar Munro, Iain Smith, Richard Baker, Mr Brian Monteith, Mr Mark Ruskell*
